div1.p: Edward J. Roye President of Liberia To His Excellency U.S. Grant President of the United States Executive Mansion Monrovia 31st March 1871

Great and Good Friend You will please pardon my intrusion upon your time and patience I hope however you will consider the native and importance of the subject which I wish to present for your consideration a suf ficient apology. My

My principal reason in writing you at this time is to present to you, as briefly as the as the native and importance of the subject will admit the present condition of the Republic of Liberia, and what she needs and must have at the crisis, to enable her government to become es tablished upon a permanent basis, and to allow her to fully develop her almost inexhaustible resources.

We have a country containing between six and seven hundred miles along the sea coast and extending far back into the interior. The civilized portion of the population is small only copmrising about twenty or twenty five thou sand. Of native Africans we have about five hundred thousand within the limits of the Republic many of whom have made more or less progress towards civilization
The history of this Colony must be familiar to every Americans. To rise pro gress and present state are well known to the statesmen of all countries.

For nearly fifty years, we have been struggling to establish a free government and to build up Republican institutions, in the land of our forefathers. far we have been successful, we must leave the civilized to fudge, We have done all that we could witht he limited at our command to accomplish the great object of our mission here.
The first emmigrants arrived on these shores comparatively poor
and ignorant having been born and reared amid the institutions of slavery where they had but for opportunities for mental improvement and for the accumulation of wealth
These colonies were orignally established under the auspices of the American Colonization Society. Since then they have been united under one government called "The Republic of Liberia"
But our government is like all other new governments poor and is therefore enable millions aid
from other sources to progress as rapidly as the interests of the people and the pro gress of the age require.

This government even with its hands tied by the want of adequate means and heavilyg oppressed by poverty has still done much to favorably to the consideration of the civil- ized world. It has done that which for many years baffled the united efforts of America and England; sir: it has demolished the slave factories on the land and broken up the lsave trade on the sea-coast, within the jurisdiction of this government.

and almost unlimited resources. if her government and people only had the means necessary to fully develop them. Her valleys and hills, forests and fields abound with the choicest products of the earth. Our forests are filled with the most valuable timber, drywoods, and gururs. We pessess a soil of unsurpassed fertility suitable for the growth of everything that will thrive written the tropics.

All we need is the necessary means to open roads, build bridges tc, that are may be enabled to cultivate and improve ourlands and bring our products to market. Is establish, a system of internal improvement; and facilitate our progress in agricultures, we need laborers saving

For the moral and mental improvement of the Americao Liberians and also the native tribes arounders, are need money. the resources of Liberia cannotr be developed. our vast ellimitable fields cannot be cultivated. and without this material aid schools and churches cannot be established among the native population. Unless we can get money the wheels of government must be stopped or move on with very slow progress.

In order then that we may rise rapidly from our infant state towards national manhood, and to enable us to keep pace with the progress of the age, to reveal the great experiment of founding a govern- ment of colored men on the soil of Africa, from
from proving to be a disgraceful failure we are compelled to solicit precuniary aid from the friends of human progress and few institutions wherever they may be found.

While it is true that Africa is our fatherland; get we regard America as our mother country and are sincere by believe that her government and people feel an interest in our welfare, and the success of our undertaking.

It is my duty to inform your Excellency that James E. Moore Esqr has so acted against the government that he is objectionally holding the Office of U.S. Vice-Consul minister Resident near this gov ernment.
